articles.headline: A Mexican Hospital, an American Surgeon, and a $5,000 Check (Yes, a Check)
articles.snippet: A novel twist on medical tourism to avoid the high cost of U.S. health care saves an employer money and even earns the patient a bonus.
articles.abstract: A novel twist on medical tourism to avoid the high cost of U.S. health care saves an employer money and even earns the patient a bonus.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANCÚN, Mexico — Donna Ferguson awoke in the resort city of Cancún before sunrise on a sweltering Saturday in July.

articles.headline: With Saudi Aramco Set to Disclose Earnings, Could an I.P.O. Be Next?
articles.snippet: The world’s largest oil producer stopped short of going public last year, but it may be about to revive its plans.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest oil producer stopped short of going public last year, but it may be about to revive its plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil producer, is set to shed new light on its financial health on Monday, a revelatory moment for the highly secretive, state-controlled company.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Can Anyone Catch Joe Biden?
articles.snippet: The Democratic candidates descend on Iowa to give it a try — and sample the best food on a stick the state fair has to offer.
articles.abstract: The Democratic candidates descend on Iowa to give it a try — and sample the best food on a stick the state fair has to offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The pack of cheering voters, sweating reporters and snapping cameras surrounding Joe Biden made its way through the Iowa State Fair like a pulsating amoeba, consuming everyone and everything in its path.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Sydney Ember and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: China Said It Closed Muslim Detention Camps. There’s Reason to Doubt That.
articles.snippet: Seven days of reporting in the Xinjiang region undermine the government’s claim that it’s winding down its network of indoctrination centers. ‘Graduates’ are still being churned out.
articles.abstract: Seven days of reporting in the Xinjiang region undermine the government’s claim that it’s winding down its network of indoctrination centers. ‘Graduates’ are still being churned out.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOTAN, China — The muscular young Uighur man sat uncomfortably, glancing occasionally at three Chinese officials in the room, as he described his state-mandated salvation in a re-education camp.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Democrats’ 2020 Problem: How to Be Tougher on Trade Than Trump
articles.snippet: Democrats are highly critical of NAFTA and China, but they will have a hard time taking a tougher line than Mr. Trump has as president.
articles.abstract: Democrats are highly critical of NAFTA and China, but they will have a hard time taking a tougher line than Mr. Trump has as president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s escalating economic war with China highlights a challenge for Democrats hoping to unseat him in 2020: They’ll have a hard time being tougher on trade than he is.

articles.headline: A Common Trait Among Mass Killers: Hatred Toward Women
articles.snippet: Misogyny and mass shootings in the United States are closely intertwined.
articles.abstract: Misogyny and mass shootings in the United States are closely intertwined.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man who shot nine people to death last weekend in Dayton, Ohio, seethed at female classmates and threatened them with violence.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Kate Taylor and Tim Arango

articles.headline: The Global Machine Behind the Rise of Far-Right Nationalism
articles.snippet: Sweden was long seen as a progressive utopia. Then came waves of immigrants — and the forces of populism at home and abroad.
articles.abstract: Sweden was long seen as a progressive utopia. Then came waves of immigrants — and the forces of populism at home and abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: RINKEBY, Sweden — Johnny Castillo, a Peruvian-born neighborhood watchman in this district of Stockholm, still puzzles over the strange events that two years ago turned the central square of this predominantly immigrant community into a symbol of multiculturalism run amok.

articles.headline: Inside Kashmir, Cut Off From the World: ‘A Living Hell’ of Anger and Fear
articles.snippet: A firsthand look inside Kashmir, the contested region the Indian government has all but cut off from the outside world, found a population that is feeling besieged and furious.
articles.abstract: A firsthand look inside Kashmir, the contested region the Indian government has all but cut off from the outside world, found a population that is feeling besieged and furious.
articles.lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — On the streets of Srinagar, Kashmir’s biggest city, security officers tied black bandannas over their faces, grabbed their guns and took positions behind checkpoints. People glanced out the windows of their homes, afraid to step outside. Many were cutting back on meals and getting hungry.
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir, Suhasini Raj and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Cathay Pacific, Icon of Hong Kong’s Rise, Now Reflects China’s Grip
articles.snippet: The airline agreed to bar employees who support or join protests from working on flights to mainland China, though it didn’t say how they would be identified.
articles.abstract: The airline agreed to bar employees who support or join protests from working on flights to mainland China, though it didn’t say how they would be identified.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Two months of boiling antigovernment protests have divided Hong Kong’s people. Now, the unrest has pitted one of the territory’s best-known international brands against some of its own employees.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Tiffany May

articles.headline: Jeffrey Epstein’s Opaque Finances Could Become Focal Point for Investigators
articles.snippet: Tens of millions of dollars flowed among Mr. Epstein’s bank accounts and companies. The question of where that money came from is likely to be a key focus after his death.
articles.abstract: Tens of millions of dollars flowed among Mr. Epstein’s bank accounts and companies. The question of where that money came from is likely to be a key focus after his death.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The money, tens of millions of dollars of it, would flow among Jeffrey Epstein’s dozens of bank accounts, shell companies and, at times, charities linked to high-powered friends.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel, Matthew Goldstein, Steve Eder and David Enrich

articles.headline: After El Paso Shooting, Will Voters Revisit Beto O’Rourke?
articles.snippet: The presidential candidate is back in the spotlight after a tragedy in a city that is core to his personal and political identity.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidate is back in the spotlight after a tragedy in a city that is core to his personal and political identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — As Beto O’Rourke waded through a crowd that had gathered Thursday night to honor victims of the mass shooting in El Paso, the struggling presidential candidate was welcomed as a hometown hero.

articles.headline: How the El Paso Killer Echoed the Incendiary Words of Conservative Media Stars
articles.snippet: Language like “invasion” and the “replacement” of Americans has increasingly become a regular part of Fox News broadcasts, Rush Limbaugh shows and other prominent conservative media.
articles.abstract: Language like “invasion” and the “replacement” of Americans has increasingly become a regular part of Fox News broadcasts, Rush Limbaugh shows and other prominent conservative media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Language like “invasion” and the “replacement” of Americans has increasingly become a regular part of Fox News broadcasts, Rush Limbaugh shows and other prominent conservative media.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Michael M. Grynbaum, Keith Collins, Rich Harris and Rumsey Taylor

articles.headline: How YouTube Radicalized Brazil
articles.snippet: YouTube built its business on keeping users hooked. This has been a gift to extremist groups. An investigation in the company’s second-biggest market found serious consequences.
articles.abstract: YouTube built its business on keeping users hooked. This has been a gift to extremist groups. An investigation in the company’s second-biggest market found serious consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: NITERÓI, Brazil — When Matheus Dominguez was 16, YouTube recommended a video that changed his life.
articles.byline: By Max Fisher and Amanda Taub

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Suspect New Nuclear Missile in Explosion That Killed 7 Russians
articles.snippet: Intelligence officials suspect that the explosion involved a prototype of a nuclear-propelled cruise missile that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has boasted can reach any corner of the earth.
articles.abstract: Intelligence officials suspect that the explosion involved a prototype of a nuclear-propelled cruise missile that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has boasted can reach any corner of the earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: American intelligence officials are racing to understand a mysterious explosion that released radiation off the coast of northern Russia last week, apparently during the test of a new type of nuclear-propelled cruise missile hailed by President Vladimir V. Putin as the centerpiece of Moscow’s arms race with the United States.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: How Facebook Is Changing to Deal With Scrutiny of Its Power
articles.snippet: In both pre-emptive and defensive ways, the social network is modifying its behavior to fend off antitrust concerns.
articles.abstract: In both pre-emptive and defensive ways, the social network is modifying its behavior to fend off antitrust concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Senator Elizabeth Warren has called for the breakup of big tech companies like Facebook. Regulators have opened investigations into Facebook’s power in social networking. Even one of Facebook’s own founders has laid out a case for why the company needs to be split up.

articles.headline: A Giant Factory Rises to Make a Product Filling Up the World: Plastic
articles.snippet: Royal Dutch Shell’s plant will produce more than a million tons of plastic, in the form of tiny pellets. Many in the Pittsburgh area see it as an economic engine, but others worry about long-term harm.
articles.abstract: Royal Dutch Shell’s plant will produce more than a million tons of plastic, in the form of tiny pellets. Many in the Pittsburgh area see it as an economic engine, but others worry about long-term harm.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONACA, Pa. — The 386-acre property looks like a giant Lego set rising from the banks of the Ohio River. It is one of the largest active construction projects in the United States, employing more than 5,000 people.

articles.headline: Saudi Aramco Says It’s ‘Ready’ for I.P.O. as It Reports Half-Year Earnings
articles.snippet: The oil giant’s chief financial officer said the timing of a public listing would depend on its “shareholder”: Saudi Arabia’s government.
articles.abstract: The oil giant’s chief financial officer said the timing of a public listing would depend on its “shareholder”: Saudi Arabia’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The oil giant Saudi Aramco is prepared for an initial public offering, its chief financial officer said on Monday, reviving the prospects for a long-awaited listing that could be a major step toward diversifying Saudi Arabia’s economy.

articles.headline: Trump Policy Favors Wealthier Immigrants for Green Cards
articles.snippet: Legal immigrants who rely on programs like food stamps and subsidized housing will find it harder to become permanent residents under a new administration proposal.
articles.abstract: Legal immigrants who rely on programs like food stamps and subsidized housing will find it harder to become permanent residents under a new administration proposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday broadened his assault on the nation’s immigration system, issuing a new rule targeting legal immigrants who want to remain in the United States but whose lack of financial resources is judged likely to make them a burden on taxpayers.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan
